Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Bedrock nitrogen and the Earth system: From geobiolgical mechanisms to climate change forecasts
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves basic research of controls on nitrogen (N) weathering rates from bedrock across an array of terrestrial ecosystems and conditions ? spanning molecular techniques to global scale modeling. This study is motivated by the need to understand how biogeochemical cycles shape integrated Earth systems and has key implications for the pace and magnitude of climate change in the face of rising fossil fuel CO2 emissions. Bedrock lithologies house >99% of all reactive N compounds (i.e., all N forms other than N2 gas) on the planet; yet, the biogeochemical importance of this vast N reservoir has been overlooked. Textbook paradigms hold that new N enters ecosystems solely from the atmosphere via biochemical fixation or as N in deposition. However, these N input pathways are incapable of explaining the high rates of N accumulation observed for many terrestrial ecosystems, constituting a major unknown in the global N budget.

As an alternative, the principal investigators suggest that the geosphere plays a major role in terrestrial N biogeochemistry ? imparting large effects on terrestrial carbon (C) cycling and climate change. They propose research to test the hypothesis that rocks of sedimentary origin represent a broadly significant source of N to the terrestrial biosphere. The research team includes geologists, biologists, pedologists, biogeochemists, and Earth system scientists. They will examine bedrock N weathering at molecular-, soil pedon-, watershed-, regional-, and global-scales. The proposed combination of state-of-the-art tools, involving lab, field, and modeling components, is novel. The molecular-scale research is focused on geobiology; it emphasizes ?rock-eating-fungi? effects on N weathering reactions, using controlled laboratory experiments and NanoSIMS (Nanometer-scale Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry) across field sites. The soil pedon, watershed and regional analyses will estimate physical and chemical weathering of nitrogen across an array of lithologies, tectonic conditions, and climates. Linkages between weathering rates and the terrestrial nitrogen cycle will be empirically investigated regionally through measures of natural nitrogen stable isotopes, and carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus chemistry. The global analyses will emphasize a new modeling scheme that couples a global biogeochemical model with a weathering model to scale the amount of rock-derived nitrogen that is available to store terrestrial carbon worldwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most plants have invisible partners that grow on their roots and help them forage for nutrients in the soil. They are called "mycorrhizal fungi". In certain ecosystems in California, we see evidence that plants have somehow acquired nitrogen--a critical nutrient--from bedrock. This finding was unexpected, since it is not easy for plants to mine bedrock for nutrients. For this project, we asked whether mycorrhizal fungi might be key. Mycorrhizal fungi can release acids that break down bedrock and release nutrients. Are they helping plants access this bedrock nitrogen?

To answer this question, we performed two tests: a greenhouse experiment, and a field study. In the greenhouse experiment, we grew plants with and without nitrogen-rich bedrock, and with and without mycorrhizal fungi. In the field experiment, we buried nitrogen-rich bedrock in a natural ecosystem, and collected it later to observe the fungi.

Altogether, we did not find evidence that the mycorrhizal fungi were helping the plants take up nitrogen from bedrock. In the greenhouse study, nitrogen did not increase in plants grown with bedrock and mycorrhizal fungi. Mycorrhizal fungi did improve uptake of phosphorus, potassium, and zinc-- just not nitrogen. In the field study, we found that mycorrhizal fungi could grow directly into the bedrock, so they have physical access. Nevertheless, we did not observe that nitrogen became depleted where the mycorrhizal fungi colonized the rock. We conclude that plants are likely acquiring the bedrock nitrogen from other means, perhaps by taking up the nitrogen after it becomes dissolved in water.

We turned our attention to other ways that fungi can contribute to recycling of nutrients within the soil. We asked whether fungi differ in their roles in ecosystems: are some more important in recycling dead material? Are others more critical for stabilizing the soil? And do certain environmental conditions favor one group more than the other? We examined the genetics and physiology of a diverse selection of fungal species, and found that they indeed sorted into broad groups based on their functions. Some fungi were exceptional at providing phosphorus to plants, others acted as superior decomposers that could break down even tough material, and another group aided soil formation. Moreover, these groups differed in their sensitivity to the environment. The phosphorus providers were knocked out by excess nitrogen. The decomposers required moderate conditions. The soil formers were particularly well-suited for stressful environments. By mapping these functions and how they are linked to environmental conditions, we are improving our understanding of consequences of nitrogen pollution and environmental stress for ecosystems.
